Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 41129 
October 2007  
 
 
 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan: Integrated Energy Model 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 5 September 2007) 
 
Currency Unit –  Pakistan rupee/s (PRe/PRs) 
PRe1.00 =  $0.0165 
$1.00 =  PRs60.58 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  CASAREM  –  Central Asia South Asia Regional Electricity Market 
  MTDF  –  Medium-Term Development Framework 
  MW  –  megawatt 
  OEA  –  Office of Energy Advisor 
  toe  –  tons of oil equivalent  
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Energy 
Subsector  –  Energy sector development 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, governance, capacity development 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets, public 
governance, organizational development 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice President  L. Jin, Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  S. O’Sullivan, Infrastructure Division, CWRD  
   
Team leader  J. Liston, Principal Energy Specialist, CWRD 
Team member  R. Stroem, Principal Energy Specialist, CWRD

I.   INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed advisory technical assistance project1 is to assist the Government of the 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan to establish an integrated energy model for analyzing the impacts 
of various strategies for meeting national energy requirements. The factors addressed cover 
finance, economics, energy supply, national resources, energy use, environmental impacts, 
technologies, energy efficiencies and sociopolitical impacts. National policy makers will be able 
to identify the various strategies to be examined and the modeling will support optimal decision 
making.  
 
2.  A monitorable condition of the second tranche of Loan 2270-PAK (Private Participation 
in Infrastructure Program)2 calls for Pakistan’s Government to complete the development of an 
integrated energy model. The Government has requested ADB assistance to establish such a 
model.   
 
3.  A  technical  assistance  (TA)  concept  note  was  circulated  on  15  May  2007.  After 
incorporation of comments, it was approved by management of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) on 22 June 2007. The Government concurs with the expected impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements and terms of reference. A notice 
requesting  expressions  of  interest  from  consulting  firms  was  posted  on  ADB’s  business 
opportunities website in July 2007.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Pakistan’s  energy  sector  includes  separate  ministries  of  Petroleum  and  Natural 
Resources; Water and Power; Planning and Development; and Environment, Transport and 
Communications. It also includes the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission. There are separate 
regulatory bodies for oil and gas, and electric power. No single ministry or regulatory body has 
overarching responsibility for energy.   
 
5.  Pakistan’s energy planning is unlikely to be optimal, or at least it is not demonstrated to 
be so. Pakistan is a net energy importer, with energy needs supplied from multiple sources. As 
such,  country  energy  analysts  believe  there  is  scope  for  optimization  through  integrated 
planning. This view is consistent with the approach of other developing and developed countries 
where least-cost energy plans are developed through a rigorous integrated process.   
 
6.  Sophisticated  computer  software  applications  that  are  available  in  the  international 
marketplace  can  model  a  country’s  overall  energy  demand  and  supply  situation.  These 
integrated energy models can help planners to assess the impacts of various policy scenarios 
and support good decision making within defined constraints. Pakistan currently does not use 
such an integrated energy modeling tool. 
 
7.  Pakistan’s  Medium-Term  Development  Framework  2005–2010  (MTDF)  sets  out  a 
challenging  program  to  achieve  8%  annual  growth  in  gross  domestic  product.  Associated 
growth in energy consumption is forecast at 12% a year, which can be compared with an annual 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 6 June 2007. 
2  ADB. 2005. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Program Cluster of Loans 
and Technical Assistance Grant to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Private Participation in Infrastructure 
Program. Manila (Loan 2270-PAK, for $600,000,000, approved on 18 August 2005).

2   
compound growth rate of 6.1% from 2000 to 2006. This expected growth will put pressure on all 
sectors of Pakistan’s primary energy supplies. 
 
8.  Pakistan’s primary energy supplies totaled 58 million tons of oil equivalent (toe) in 2005–
2006. The supplies comprise natural gas (50%), oil (28%), hydro electricity (13%), coal (7%), 
nuclear energy (1%) and liquefied petroleum gas (less than 1%). All domestic natural gas 
production is consumed and, without higher production, growth will need to be met through 
imports. The combination of rising oil consumption and flat oil production has led to rising oil 
imports. In addition, a lack of refining capacity leaves Pakistan heavily dependent on petroleum 
product imports. Electricity supply is limited due to insufficient generation availability, with an 
estimated 1,500 megawatts (MW) of demand unmet. Meanwhile, electricity demand is forecast 
to grow by 8% a year during 2005–2015. 
 
9.  Pakistan is responding to this energy development challenge by pursuing a wide range 
of domestic and imported energy projects. Growth in domestic gas production is not forecast to 
meet demand. Several international gas pipeline projects are under development while liquid 
natural gas import options are being investigated. Development of the significant but challenging 
coal reserves in Tharparkar (Thar) Desert is being studied by the Government. Consideration is 
also being given to 2,000 MW of power-generation projects in the private sector, using imported 
coal. Further, the Government intends to proceed with a large multipurpose dam project on the 
Indus River to cater for irrigation needs and to supply about 8,000 MW of electric generating 
capacity, and investigations are being conducted currently into the Central Asia South Asia 
Regional Electricity Market (CASAREM) project to import more than 2,000 MW of electricity 
from Tajikistan and Kyrgyz Republic via Afghanistan. Renewable energy projects are being 
promoted, with a target of 10% of energy mix to be met from such sources by 2015. Several 
energy efficiency projects are at an early stage of development.  Meanwhile, a lack of energy 
efficiency standards has contributed to high carbon dioxide intensity.   
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA will support optimal energy sector development that will facilitate economic 
growth. The outcome will be a functioning energy planning unit producing regular integrated 
analysis of strategic energy options. A trained energy planning team will be established. It will (i) 
operate and maintain the model and (ii) propose strategies for meeting energy requirements at 
the least cost and in a manner that is technically and financially sustainable and environmentally 
acceptable, for consideration by national policy makers.   
 
11.  Outputs of the energy model will be simulation results identifying the following. 
 
(i)  Least-cost energy systems.  
(ii)  Cost-effective responses to restrictions on emissions.  
(iii)  Long-term energy balances under different scenarios.  
(iv)  Impact of new technologies.  
(v)  Effects of regulations, taxes and subsidies. 
, Board (ovf iD) irectBoresn, eMfiatsn aogfe rmegeinot,n oarl  sctoaoffp, aenradt imonay.  be preliminar

3
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  Data  across  Pakistan’s  energy  sector  will  be  reviewed.  This  will  include  economic, 
financial and technical data on (i) import and domestic energy supplies based on gas, oil, coal, 
and nuclear, as well as renewable supplies based on hydro, biomass, wind and solar; (ii) energy 
consumption by sector and type; and (iii) environmental, efficiency, and sociopolitical matters. 
Any data omissions and/or inconsistencies will be rectified and a set of base historical and 
projected data required as input for the integrated energy model will be produced.   
 
13.  The consultant will review, evaluate and extract the lessons learned by similarly situated 
countries which have used energy planning and optimization models. 
 
14.  Leading international suppliers of integrated energy models will be identified together 
with  the  advantages  and  disadvantages  of  the  various  model  types  based  on  Pakistan’s 
particular needs. The options available will be reported, as will the estimated hardware and 
software set-up and running costs.   
 
15.  Should a specific model or a complementary set of models be selected, then single 
source procurement will be used. Should several suitable alternative models be identified, then 
tender inquiry documents will be prepared and issued to pre-qualified suppliers. Procurement 
will be (i) carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended 
from time to time) through limited international bidding or direct contracting; and (ii) delegated to 
the executing agency with the full support of the TA consultant.    
 
16.  The supplier of the integrated energy model will provide training on the model for the 
 
counterpart team and support services during commissioning and operations. The consultant 
will provide training on general energy planning.   
 
17.  The consultant, together with the counterpart team, will utilize the model to examine a 
range of alternative scenarios for energy sector development and to produce medium and long-
term energy plans. The consultant will coach the counterpart team to ensure an energy planning 
unit is functioning on completion of the consultant’s contract. Thereafter, the energy planning 
team  will  conduct  continuous  reviews  of  the  sector  and  issue  regular  national  integrated 
planning reports. It is envisaged that these will be annual reports in the early years. 
   
C.  Cost and Financing  
18.  The TA cost estimate is $2.5 million, of which $2 million will come from ADB and $0.5 
million from the Government. The ADB component will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
TA funding program. See Appendix 2 for details of the cost estimates and financing plan.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  Pakistan’s Planning Commission will be the executing and implementing agency. The 
commission has sufficient resources to make offices and counterparts available for the project 
and is a possible permanent location for the future planning team. In this regard, a study to

consultant’s  terms  of  reference.    The  Office  of  the  Energy  Advisor  (OEA)3  of  the  Prime 
                                                 
3 ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Operational Support to the Office of the 
Energy Advisor (OEA). Manila (TA 4610-PAK, approved on 14 July 2005, for $150,000).

4   
Minister’s  secretariat,  which  conducts  planning  studies  and  provides  policy  advice,  has 
confirmed that the knowledge and expertize gathered through previous projects will be made 
available to the Planning Commission during project implementation.     
 
20.  The TA is expected to begin in early 2008 and be carried out over 12 months by an 
international consulting firm supported by a domestic consultant. Thirty-two staff-months of 
international  consultant  and  60  staff-months  of  domestic  consultant  will  be  required.  The 
international  consultant  and  proposed  specialists  will  be  expected  to  have  demonstrated 
experience in energy sector planning. The team of international consultants will include (i) the 
team leader/planning specialist; (ii) three energy-supply specialists covering coal, oil and gas, 
and power; (iii) two energy-demand specialists covering oil, gas and power, and transport; (iv) 
an environmental specialist; (v) an information technology specialist; and (vi) a financial analyst.  
Bidders will be required to submit a full technical proposal. A consulting firm will be selected in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). A quality and cost-based selection method will be applied, using a full technical proposal. 
 
21.  An international consulting firm (the consultant) with expertise in energy sector planning 
and supported by a domestic consultant will assist in designing, procuring, populating and 
establishing  a  computerized  software  model  of  Pakistan’s  energy  sector  and  in  training  a 
domestic counterpart team. The counterpart team, to be selected at an early stage in the 
project, will be the foundation of the new Pakistan energy planning unit.   
 
22.  The consultant will prepare (i) an inception report by month one of the project and 
thereafter  monthly  progress  reports;  (ii)  a  report  by  month  three  on  lessons  learned  from 
comparable countries, model options and costs; (iii) a draft final report and a final report on the 
Pakistan  Strategic  Energy  Plan  2009–2029  by  months  10  and  12;  and  (iv)  a  project 
performance report by month 11.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
23.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000.00 on a grant basis to the Government of Pakistan 
for an integrated energy model.

7
Appendix  3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The project is to assist the Government of Pakistan to establish an integrated energy 
model for analyzing the impacts of various strategies for meeting energy requirements. The 
factors addressed include finance, economics, energy supply, national resources, energy use, 
environmental  impacts,  technologies,  energy  efficiencies  and  sociopolitical  impacts.  An 
international consultant with experience in energy sector planning and supported by a domestic 
consultant  will  assist  in  designing,  procuring,  populating  and  establishing  a  computerized 
software model of Pakistan’s energy sector and in training a domestic counterpart team. The 
counterpart team will be the foundation of the new Pakistan energy planning unit.   
 
1.  The Consultant’s Tasks  
(i)  Review existing data across Pakistan’s energy sector. This will include economic, 
financial and technical data on (a) import and domestic energy supplies of all 
sources; (b) energy consumption by sector and type; and (c) environmental, 
efficiency and sociopolitical matters. Any data omissions and/or inconsistencies 
to be rectified and a set of base historical and projected data required as input for 
the integrated energy model will be produced.  
.   
(ii)  Review, evaluate and extract the lessons learned by similarly situated countries 
which have used energy planning and optimization models.   
 
(iii)  Review  Pakistan’s  energy  sector  institutional  framework  and  identify  an 
appropriate  institutional  location  and  reporting  arrangements  for  the  energy 
planning team. Propose the structure of the team and desired skill sets of team 
members. Identify requirements for energy planning and staff training on the 
model.  
 
(iv)  Identify  the  leading  energy  models  that  are  available  in  the  international 
marketplace for national energy planning. Based on Pakistan’s needs, identify 
the advantages and disadvantages of the various models. Identify software and 
hardware needs and estimate set-up and running costs. Report and rank the 
options available.   
 
(v)  Assist in energy model procurement by developing tender inquiry documents to 
be issued to pre-qualified suppliers. The inquiry documents should specify the 
required model type and outputs in addition to software, hardware and client 
training  needs.  Should  a  single  model  or  complementary  set  of  models  be 
agreed, then sole source procurement will be used. Evaluate and report on 
offers. 
 
(vi)  Propose and calculate indicators for measuring impact and benefit of integrated 
energy planning.  Base Case (business as usual before integrated planning) to

8   
Appendix  3 
(vii)  Working  with  the  selected  local  counterpart  team,  set  up  the  model  and 
customize it as required, populate with necessary input data and execute a 
series  of  model  runs  examining  a  range  of  alternative  scenarios.  Before 
completion of the project the consultant, together with the counterpart team, shall 
produce and issue the first report on model outputs and findings. 
 
(viii)  Implement overseas and domestic training of counterpart team. 
 
(ix)  Coach the counterpart team to ensure an energy planning unit is functioning on 
completion of the consultant’s contract. 
 
B.  Composition of Consultants

3.  The composition of the international consultant team will be four experts, one each for 
specialties 1, 7, 8 and 9. For specialties 2, 3 and 4, the consultant may propose one, two or 
three  experts  to  cover  one  or  more  special  areas.  Similarly,  for  specialties  5  and  6,  the 
consultant may propose one or two individuals to cover one or both areas.  
 
4.  The proposed experts, whether covering single or grouped specialties, shall have the 
requisite experience and qualifications for the special area to be covered adequately.   
 
5.  The  composition  of  the  domestic  consultants  will  be  proposed  by  the  international 
consultant as the needs are identified during project implementation. It is envisaged that 60 
staff-months of domestic consultants are required to assist the international consultant in (i) 
collecting  data  and  information  from  national  and  local  sources;  (ii)  reviewing  existing 
documentation, studies, and reports; (iii) organizing consultations with stakeholders; and (iv) 
undertaking field surveys.
